description.narrative:
Project Outcomes (i) Stakeholder Effects: (a) Increased access to residential housing finance: Due to the continued growth in housing demand, most recent estimates indicate a shortage of more than 100,000 units, which is significant for a country with a population of less than 1.4 million; and (b) Increased affordability in housing finance: In T&T wages have not been able to keep pace with the sharp increases in housing prices; thus, households' purchasing power has significantly eroded. For the last two decades the housing affordability ratio in T&T has been at 10:1 vs. international rates of median housing, where a ratio above 4:1 indicates a serious lack of affordability. In this context, RBL is expanding its focus on catering to the middle-income segments where affordability has historically been a major barrier to home ownership. (ii) Economy Wide Effects: Many of the mortgages supported by the Project are expected to finance new homes; hence, the impact on jobs could be significant. The IFC model estimates the creation of approximately 2.7 jobs per newly built housing unit financed and the value-added impact per housing unit financed to be approximately US$165,000.
Contribution to Market Creation (i) Competitiveness: Given that RBL is the largest player in the banking sector, the Project will support the Bank as they continue their expansion strategy into the middle-income residential mortgage market, which is expected to contribute to changing the banking sector's risk perception of the segment. Over time other financial institutions will replicate RBL's approach and cater to the growing housing finance demand from middle-income borrowers.

The proposed project (the Project) consists of a subordinated debt of up to US$75 million to Republic Bank Limited (RBL or the Bank) in Trinidad and Tobago (T&T or the Country) structured as a 7-year bullet loan. The main purpose of the loan is to strengthen RBLs capital base and to support the growth of the Banks mortgage loan portfolio in T&T.
